Award.AwardTitle: Logarithmic geometry and its applications to moduli and birational geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The work of this proposal lies at the intersection of string theory from physics and algebraic geometry. In string theory, particles are replaced by small loops of strings moving in space-time. Conjecturally, the space-time is ten-dimensional. Over the four-dimensional space-time we are aware of, there is a six-dimensional fibration whose fiber is known as the Calabi-Yau manifold. The Gromov-Witten invariants serve as important ingredients in the study of Calabi-Yau manifolds and string theory. Since the discovery of the Gromov-Witten invariants, new insights are developing rapidly, which also provide many interesting new approaches to classical problems from algebraic geometry. The calculation of Gromov-Witten invariants is extremely difficult to perform on Calabi-Yau manifolds. This project aims to develop a new calculation method of Gromov-Witten invariants, and to apply the developments to produce new understandings in algebraic geometry.

The major focus of this project is to study the degeneration of Gromov-Witten theory. This will be carried out from the perspective of stable logarithmic maps developed jointly with Dan Abramovich, and independently by Mark Gross and Bernd Siebert. In particular, the PI proposes to prove a general gluing formula of logarithmic Gromov-Witten invariants. The theory of stable logarithmic maps also provides a useful tool for the study of rational curves on quasi-projective varieties. Another part of this project is to generalize Mori's theory in the non-proper cases, and to have a further understanding of the birational geometry of quasi-projective varieties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on questions in algebraic geometry, which is the study of algebraic varieties, defined as the collections of solutions to polynomials.  Algebraic geometry has important applications in control theory, error-correcting codes, and geometric modeling. One major part of this project on the study of moduli theory is closely related to applications in theoretical physics. Instead of studying a single geometric object, the moduli theory is the study of collections of objects with certain common constraints. These collections in many situations again form varieties, and carry rich geometric information. They are used to define and study Gromov-Witten invariants that are important numbers in string theory used to describe the structure of our universe. During this project, with his collaborators, much effort of the PI has been devoted to the study of Gromov-Witten invariants along a process varying the collections of objects of the corresponding moduli theory, called logarithmically smooth degenerations. This project advances the understanding of the structure of Gromov-Witten invariants along logarithmically smooth degenerations, and provides new computational tools to calculate these important numbers.


Another major topic of this project is birational geometry, a study of a fundamental relation between varieties called birational equivalence under which two varieties are equivalent if they only differ along very small loci. During this project, with his collaborator Yi Zhu, the PI applied the techniques developed in the study of degeneration of Gromov-Witten invariants to investigate A1-connectedness -- an interesting birational property of varieties. This work develops tools for studying A1-connectedness using logarithmic geometry along with many interesting examples of A1-connected varieties. It further provides connections between the A1-connectedness on the geometric side and integral solutions to polynomial equations with certain coefficients on the arithmetic side.


The PI's work had broader impact in training graduate students and young researchers. During the project, the PI has taught two graduate courses, and led one reading group with graduate students on topics related to his research. He is now working with his first graduate student on problems that are natural extensions of this project. He co-organized the Boston College-Northeastern Algebraic Geometry Conference in Spring 2016, Fall 2016, and Fall 2017 which is a one-day conference series with 4 to 5 research talks. It attracts around 30 researchers from the greater Boston area, most of whom are junior researchers. In Fall 2017, he co-organized the Winter Young Algebraic Geometer Workshop in Shenzhen, China. This is a week long workshop bringing together young algebraic geometers to disseminate their recent research and to foster discussion. Finally, the PI has given several talks on his research during this grant period at a number of seminars, workshops, and conferences.
